dt: {bc}to make a liar of (oneself) under or as if under oath

pt: {sc}abjure{/sc} {sc}renounce{/sc} {sc}forswear{/sc} {sc}recant{/sc} {sc}retract{/sc} mean to withdraw one's word or professed belief. {sc}abjure{/sc} implies a firm and final rejecting or abandoning often made under oath.

pt.t: {it}abjured{/it} the errors of his former faith

pt: {sc}renounce{/sc} may carry the meaning of disclaim or disown.

pt.t: {it}renounced{/it} abstract art and turned to portrait painting

pt: {sc}forswear{/sc} may add an implication of perjury or betrayal.
{sc}recant{/sc} stresses the withdrawing or denying of something professed or taught.

pt.t: if they {it}recant{/it} they will be spared

pt: {sc}retract{/sc} applies to the withdrawing of a promise, an offer, or an accusation.

pt.t: the newspaper had to {it}retract{/it} the story

et: Middle English {it}forsweren{/it}, from Old English {it}forswerian{/it}, from {it}for-{/it} + {it}swerian{/it} to swear
shortdef: to make a liar of (oneself) under or as if under oath
to reject or renounce under oath

dt: {bc}to make a liar of (oneself) under or as if under oath

shortdef: to make a liar of (oneself) under or as if under oath
to reject or renounce under oath
